data.title: Strange mix of goods and so-so
data.text: On WB Main just before you leave Springfield, TEENSY parking lot, old dead decor, (like its time to dump the empty fish tanks). Ample seating. Asian staff and almost all patrons are Asian. HUGE PORTIONS but not cheap, $10.50 combo plate, but it is a big plate and filled edge to edge. BBQ pork very tender, good rice, chow mein was so fresh it was chewy, mar far was fine but not special, same with shrimp- breaded, fried, good, but not great. Service friendly but only 1 person waiting on people so if they get busy you sit a bit. Soup was fine. Clean but not sparkly clean. It shows its age, and you'd say "forget it" but the portions are killer and they are open Mondays unlike most of the other Asian restaurants in town. C+ , worth a try to see how you feel about it. I'd give the chow mein and bbq pork A grades otherwise c and c+

data.title: New owners - good food!
data.text: I've eaten here for a long time and was concerned when I found out there were new owners. But the place looks better actually (e.g., the horrible, nasty lobster tank is gone) and the food was really, really good. I will definitely be going back.

data.title: Best Chinese food in Lane County
data.text: Having spent a year in Taiwan, I've had a hard time finding AUTHENTIC Chinese food.  Spring Garden has it IF you order from the non-combo type of menu.  You know it's good when 1/2 the clients are Chinese and the menu is in both Chinese and English.

data.title: King snake? Got you covered.
data.text: I learned of this place from a Korean co-worker, who likes the king snake. They serve an amazing array of fresh and dried seafood dishes, all of which I've tried were phenomenal. Service was attentive and smooth. Prices are a wee high, but this is not standard Chinese-American food. No General Tso here.

data.title: Lunch stop
data.text:
We were here on a velomobile ride. Some of the group opted for lunch at Spring Garden. Overall, food was deemed to be average (based on the opinion of a person who used to live in China) and the service was deemed to be great. 

This seems like a worthy place to stop for Chinese even if you expect true Chinese food. In that way, it is better than some. Being from out of town, we cannot compare with other local Chinese establishments-if there are any.

data.title: Unremarkable
data.text: Our two lunch entrées were very ordinary.  The vegetarian egg rolls were slightly better than average.  The facility needs an update--especially the washroom.  The server was fairly attentive, at least.

data.title: Best in Eugene/Springfield area
data.text: Always busy especially when UO is in session. Great food with many dishes you don't see many places. This place has a big following with Asian students from UO. Our favorite dish is the War Won Ton soup. Meal in it self. Highly recommend if you can get in.

data.title: Truly Chinese
data.text: There is a reason you always find numerous Chinese people in this establishment. Authentic and tasty, a combination that will definitely get you hooked and come back for more.

data.title: Food still good, service improved!
data.text:
Updating my previous review.  We have returned to eat several times since, and I am pleased to report that we have gotten better service on all our visits (although we have not been back on a Saturday night).  The service is usually reasonably good, and has been adequate and normal.

We have tried many more dishes and most are tasty.  My brother-in-law, who searches out places for hot-and-sour soup, thinks that their hot-and-sour soup is quite good.  We all like their crab wontons.  The general tso's chicken is pretty good (for Oregon).  They have a fair amount of variety, aside from the usual offerings.

data.title: Good food and good service
data.text:
My wife and I had dinner on a Friday night, and although the restaurant was busy (20-30 guests), we were seated quickly, received the menus and water quickly, and had our order taken quickly.  My wife ordered the chicken chow fun dinner ($8.95, with about 3/4"-wide noodles rather than the thin noodes of chow mein), while I ordered the kung pan fish filet dinner with fried rice.  Both dinners came with soup, we chose the very good hot and sour soup.  The entrees arrived in about 20 minutes and turned our to be huge portions, especially the chow fun.  We ate most of the fish but hardly touched the chow mein (which we took home for dinner the next night).  The fish was slightly spicy, just right for our tastes, and was not a single filet, as I had expected, but small, larget than bite-size pieces.  The fish was in a very tasty thick brown sauce, with mushrooms, bamboo shoots, green peppers, and tiny very hot red peppers   Both dishes were very good.  The restaurant does not have a wine list.  When we asked the waitress what was available, she told us "only cabernet sauvignon.''  We would have preferred a white wine with chicken and fish.  

The menu included an incredibile list of "Specialty Dishes" that may appeal more to oriental persons than others.  There were at least 50 items, including duck tongue, spicy tripe, bbq chicken kidneys, king snake, braised fish head, spicy sea snails, and many less exotic dishes.  Prices for most dishes were between $8 and $15, but there were some in the $20-30 range, including whole chicken and whole fish.  The restaurant had three fish tanks that had live lobsters, rock fish, and shrimp (all quite large).  

Two flat-screen TVs on opposite walls of the dining room played a Chinese move (Channel CCTV4) with Chinese subtitles, with the sound turned off.. The noise level was a bit high, both from activities in the kitchen (which was partially open to the dining room), and from guests talking in the dining room.  But overall a pleasant experience.  By the way, the full name of the restaurant is Spring Garden Seafood Restaurant, and it deserves that name based on the wide variety of seafood dishes being offered.

data.title: Great & Cheap!
data.text: My all time favorite Chinese restraurant. Very flavorful food really cheap. Less than $10 for dinner including tea.

data.title: Good food, bad service
data.text:
We've been looking for a good Chinese place in the Eugene/Springfield area for a long time.  The food at Spring Garden is good, the best of the Chinese restaurants we've tried here so far.  And I liked the atmosphere.  Didn't catch any conversation at the tables around us, because none of the other customers were speaking English, and many others seemed to be enjoying cooking piles of intriguing looking food in little propane powered pots on their tables- cool.  
The service, however, was rather terrible.   Only one waitress on a Saturday night, long wait for everything including drink orders, she got two of our orders wrong, difficult to get her attention (and even when we did, she didn't fully listen before sprinting off).  Our glasses were empty most of the evening, as she didn't refill soft drinks until we asked, and then only once.  
I'm giving this place four out of five since it's hard to find decent Chinese here.  But be warned.  Maybe try to go on a weeknight, and be proactive and assertive about getting attention before you end up waiting.
